title: PPIAF - Sibiti water supply project
description: In 2005, Weihai International Economic Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) completed a water project in Sibiti, Congo. The financing came from the Chinese government in the form of a grant. The total project cost was $6 million, while the Chinese commitment was $5.79 million; References to this project outside of PPIAF cannot be found; PPIAF-ID:87
sources: PPIAF_Consultant, Other English Source, Non-media
implementing_agency: Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC), Private Sector
donor_agency: Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC), Private Sector
factiva_sources: PPIAF_Consultant, Factiva, Non-media

title: PPIAF - Construction of terminals, tower and power control center at Ollombo Airport
description: In 2007, a commitment was made as part of a China-Congo Rep. package deal. One of the projects was the construction of terminals towers, Fire-fighting centre, water and hydrogen storage, and a power control center at an airport in Ollombo. The contract value was $62.38 million, but a PPIAF consultant placed the Chinese commitment at $56 million. The total building floorage area was 18,000 sq. meters, project construction began in October 2008 and was completed. The contractor for this project was the China Jiangsu International Economic-Technical Cooperation Corporation.; PPIAF-ID:90
sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201206110020.html, Google US, International media report; http://www.zjgj.com/en/viewprojectcontent.asp?id=41&class=52, Google US, Non-media
factiva_sources: http://allafrica.com/stories/201206110020.html, Factiva, International media report; http://www.zjgj.com/en/viewprojectcontent.asp?id=41&class=52, Factiva, Non-media

title: PPIAF - Rehabilitate Brazaville Airport project (Maya-Maya international airport)
description: As part of a China-Congo package deal, an agreement was signed to renovate the Maya-Maya International Airport in Brazzaville. The project included the construction of two terminals, two landing strips, and a transformer sub-station. The total cost is $160 million, and is currently being implemented by the Weihai International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co. Ltd. (WIETC). With these improvements, the Congolese government hopes to accomodate 2 million passengers a year. Construction is expected to be completed by the end of 2012.; PPIAF-ID:91
sources: http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/home/2012-06/28/content_15530214.htm, Google US, Donor media or official; http://www.wietc.com/xx.asp?id=31306

title: Debt Cancellation
description: On May 25, 2001, Chinese deputy economy minister Zhang Xiang signed an agreement cancelling $75 million of the Republic of the Congo's maturing debt.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010712dx5p02y3r&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report; http://www.gov.cn/zwjw/2006-06/18/content_313579.htm, Local Language Source, Donor media or official

title: PPIAF - Road linking Brazaville and Pointe-Noire
description: As part of a China-Congo package deal, China State Construction Engineering Corp. (CSCEC) was contracted to build roads linking Brazzaville and Pointe-noire. The length of the first phase road is 160 km, while the project cost for the whole project is 500 million USD. The project was started in October 2009. As of April 8, 2012, this project was still in implementation, and has been slowed down due to protests over working conditions. ; PPIAF-ID:89

title: Preferential Loan
description: On June 30, Mathias Dzon, the Congolese Finance Minister, reported that China had authorized a loan of 15 billion XAF at a preferential rate. No details were available on the terms of the loan, and the projects financed with this loan have yet to be determined.STAFF_NOTES:It is possible that this loan may be related to the soft loan referenced in project ID # 12821.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010820dw6u02phh&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Infrastructure Grant
description: On November 21, 2003, China announced a grant of 3 billion XAF to the Republic of the Congo with the purpose of rebuilding the county's war-torn infrastructure. Chinese ambassador Wo Ruidi was quoted as saying that a Chinese team was in the country evaluating the construction needs. The projects funded with this grant and their statuses are yet unknown.May be connected with ID#447 and ID#23762.
sources: http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=47380, Factiva, International media report
factiva_sources: http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=47380, Factiva, International media report

title: Athletics Centre, Radio station, Radio and Television Centre, and Foreign Affairs Building
description: In January 2003, the Chinese government gave a donation of 1.5 billion XAF which funded the renovation of the Alphonse Massamba-debat athletics center, the construction of a radio station in Djoue, the Maison de la Radio and Television at PK 13 (Brazzaville), and the foreign affairs building. The implementing agency for these projects cannot yet be found.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020031128dzbl004c5, Factiva, International media report; http://congo-story.skyrock.com/609645706-Congo-Chine-un-modele-de-cooperation-Sud-Sud-Congo-China-a-model-of.html, Google US, Non-media

title: Imboulou Dam
description: In January of 2004, the China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) started work on a 120 mw dam to supply power to Brazzaville. The total project cost was estimated at $280 million for the dam, and construction was expected to be completed in 2009. Seller's credits of $238 million were provided by the Export Import Bank of China to the China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corp. A PPIAF consultant said that this loan was backed by oil guarantees. On May 7, 2011, the dam was finally inaugurated by the president, Denis Sassou Nguesso. In the end, the project cost $340 million to complete, which included a 60 km access road and workers housing. ;PPIAF-ID:84

title: Solar Module Projects
description: On April 23, 2007, the Republic of the Congo led a trade delegation to Solar EnerTech Corp. for a purchasing mission. The solar projects were stated to have financial support from both the Congolese and Chinese governments, with the China Industrial and Agricultural Machinery Import and Export Company acting as an intermediary agent to manage the export of completed solar modules. The current status of this project is yet unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=ITWR000020070423e34n002hn&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Cement plant
description: In 2002, the China Road and Bridge Corp., with loans from the China Exim Bank, began renovations on the Congo Cement Company's factory in Loutete in the Bouenza region following its destruction in the war. Upon its competition it was renamed the New Cement Company of the Congo (Sonocc), and a joint-venture was set up to manage it, with the Chinese government as a share holder. The factory employs 200 Congolese and has an output of 300,000 tons of cement per year, although some complaints have been raised over wages and treatment. The financial amount and exact start date are yet unknown.May be connected with ID#429.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020070508e358001p6&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report; http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2012-07/11/content_15567274.htm, Google US, Donor media or official

title: Hospitals
description: On December 28, 2009, the Republic of the Congo received a 3.5 billion XAF donation from China to update their health facilities. The agreement was signed between Congolese Finance Minister Gilbert Ondongo and Chinese Ambassador Li Shuli. The Mfilou Hospital in the 7th Brazzaville district, the Landini Hospital in the Pointe Noire region, the Talangaï hospital in the 6th Brazzaville district, and the Owando hospital in Cuvette were cited as some of the projects to have been completed by the Chinese government.
sources: http://congo-story.skyrock.com/609645706-Congo-Chine-un-modele-de-cooperation-Sud-Sud-Congo-China-a-model-of.html, Google US, Non-media; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020091229e5ct001jl&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, Donor media or official

title: Interest-Free Loan Agriculture and Health
description: On December 21, 2010, Chinese Ambassador to Congo Li Shuli and Congolese Minister of Finance Gilbert Ondongo signed a 500 million CNY interest-free loan agreement for developing medical care and agriculture as part of a larger economic and technical cooperation agreement. The loan is to be repaid by the Congolese government in a 10-year period from July 1, 2020 to June 30, 2030. The projects to be financed with this loan are to be agreed upon by both governments. The exact nature of these projects and their current status are yet unknown.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020101221e6cl00bf5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, Donor media or official
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=XNEWS00020101221e6cl00bf5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, Donor media or official

title: Economic Aid for anti-malarials, agricultural centers, schools, and training
description: In 2006, presumably as part of a FOCAC commitment, China decided to grant the Republic of the Congo an aid of 30 million yuan, donated anti-malaria drugs, aided agricultural demonstration centers and rural schools, providing professional and technical personnel training. Regarding the agricultural demonstration centers, sometime before 2011, at least one center of 59 hectares near Brazzaville had been completed and several experts have been trained. There may be plans for additional demonstration centers.
sources: http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200606/20060602501299.html, Local Language Source, Donor media or official; http://www.finance-ol.com/2011/09/congo-brazzaville-praised-the-minister-of-agriculture-china-agricultural-technical-assistance/, Google US, International media report

title: PPIAF - Oyo Water Supply project
description: In 2008, the Chinese government provided a grant for the construction of water supply projects near Oyo city in the Congo. The boreholes have flows estimated between 40 and 60 cubic meters per hour, and a processing station has a 150 cubic meter/hour flow rate. Also included in the grant was the construction of a 500 cubic meter water-tower, technical and administrative buildings, canals, as well as the supply and setting up of five generators. The implementing agency was the Weihai International Economic and Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd. (WIETC). The project began in December 2008, was completed in May 2010, and had officially handed over to the Congolese government on March 25, 2011.
sources: http://www.sourcejuice.com/1432668/2011/03/28/Congo-Brazzaville-attend-Chinese-Ambassador-Shuli-Austrian-government-aid/, Google US, Donor media or official; http://www.xm88.cn/Article/390.html

title: PPIAF - Well to the treasury road
description: (PPIAF) A 7.9 km road is in implementation at a cost of $25.77 million. Commitment year, location, implementing agency, and dates are unclear. PPIAF-ID:95
sources: PPIAF_Consultant
factiva_sources: PPIAF_Consultant, Factiva

title: Preferential loan for MA60 jets
description: After a series of talks between Wen Jiabao and Congolese officials on June 19, 2006, a series of agreements were signed, including an agreement signed by the Export-Import Bank's Li Ruogu for a loan agreement to purchase MA60 aircraft at a discounted price. The MA60 is manufactured by Xi'an Aircraft International Corporation. Congo has purchased MA60 aircraft after this point, and has signed a contract in 2011 to purchase more in 2012.

title: Medicine and Computers for Hospitals
description: On June 19, 2006, Wen Jiabao made an official visit to the Congo, where he presented medicine and drugs for the Congolese hospitals currently being helped by Chinese medical teams. An amount for this in-kind contribution is yet unknown.
sources: http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200606/20060602501299.html, Local Language Source, Donor media or official

title: Study Abroad
description: In an official visit to the Congo, Wen Jiabao claimed that China funds scholarships to allow over 30 Congolese students to study abroad in China per year. The commitment year or financial amount for this project are yet unknown.
sources: http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200606/20060602501299.html, Local Language Source, Donor media or official

title: Interest-Free Development Loan
description: On May 24, 2001, Chinese deputy economy minister Zhang Xiang signed an agreement that included, among other things, an interest-free loan of 3 billion XAF slated for development. The projects financed with this loan have yet to be determined.The other part of this same agreement is ID#334
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010712dx5p02y3r&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Soft Loan
description: In August of 2000, China granted the Republic of the Congo a 'soft loan' of 20 billion XAF for post-conflict reconstruction. The exact start and end dates for project associated with this loan are yet unknown.STAFF_NOTES:It is possible that this soft loan may be related to the preferential loan referenced in project ID # 415.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=lba0000020010712dx5p02y3r&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Borehole Water Project
description: In November of 2003, Chinese experts were in the middle of a project to provide water to the outskirts of Brazzaville using boreholes. The start date, commitment year, end date, current status, implementing agency, and financial amount cannot be found for this project.
sources: http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=47380, Factiva, International media report
factiva_sources: http://www.irinnews.org/printreport.aspx?reportid=47380, Factiva, International media report

title: No. 2 Highway Project
description: As part of a China-Congo. Rep. Package deal, China Road and Bridge Corp. commenced construction on a highway connecting Owando, Makoua, and Mambili (Highway No. 2) on May 7, 2008. The contract period was 36 months, and the road is 126.65 km long with a 160 meter bridge over the Mambili river. The project also included the construction of seven local schools along the road, and some assistance in the construction of a maternal and child health center at Owando. The project was inaugurated by the Congolese president on May 15, 2012 at Ossangou and was completed for a cost of 162 billion XAF. The work employed 350 Chinese and 700 Congolese workers. ; PPIAF-ID:97
sources: http://cg.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200805/20080505524689.html?2191604662=4161195480; http://www.crbc.com/en/newsInfo.asp?NID=205, Google US, Non-media; http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=ATCHBN0020110823e77t0002f&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, Donor media or official; http://www.congo-site.com/Denis-Sassou-N-Guesso-inaugure-le-troncon-routier-Owando-Makoua-Mambili_a12546.html, Google US, Recipient media or official

title: University Library
description: In 2007, Wo Ruidi, Chinese ambassador to the Rep. of Congo, signed an agreement with the Republic of the Congo Ministry of Higher Education to finance the construction of the Library of the University of Marien Ngouabi in Brazzaville. The cost is estimated at $4 million. The funds were disbursed in 2010. The current status of this project, implementing agency, start, and end dates cannot be determined.
sources: http://www.panapress.com/China-grants-Congo-FCFA-3.7b-loan--13-747801-18-lang2-index.html, Google US, International media report; http://leaks.hohesc.us/?view=07BRAZZAVILLE406, Google US, Non-media

title: Moukoukoulou Dam
description: In 2004, restoration work began on the four-turbine, 75 mw Moukoukoulou Dam in Mindouli, Bouenza District, which was damaged during the 1999 civil war, with Chinese assistance. In 2007, the dam was fully reconstructed and recommissioned. The dam was originally built by Chinese technicians in 1974. The cost of the rehabilitation totalled $12 million. The implementing agency is yet unknown.This project may have received Chinese assistance through the war-torn infrastructure grant ID#429.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=EIUBF00020040131e01g0000d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report; http://www.irinnews.org/Report/71927/CONGO-Rebuilt-dam-brings-power-to-rural-areas, Google US, International media report
